page.title: 11CAYTON AND OSGODBY VILLAGES
page.content: These lie in a valley 30 to 70 metres above sea level, between the North Yorkshire Moors and the Yorkshire Wolds, with the North Sea (Cayton Bay) the Eastern boundary and Scarborough 6 km to the North. The surrounding farmland is mixed, sheep and dairy farming. The industrial estate on the western boundary provides employment in light engineering, electrical engineering, coachworks, printing, adhesives and plastics. Cayton is mentioned in the Domesday Book as Caitune. Few of the older buildings survive.Osgodby is entered as Asgozbi.It flourished in the 12th to 14th century then became a deserted village. It has been rebuilt since 1945. The villages today consist of 4 new estates of private housing, both houses and bungalows.
